awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: New class of near-infrared fluorophores derived from DNA-templated silver clusters for deep tissue imaging
awd_abstract_narration:
Since near-infrared (NIR) light penetrates much farther into biological tissues than visible light, NIR fluorescence microscopy allows noninvasive imaging deep into tissues and even whole organisms. However, deep tissue imaging is currently hindered by a lack of small, bright, non-toxic biolabels that emit NIR light. This project will develop brightly fluorescent NIR biolabels by harnessing a class of promising tunable nanomaterials called DNA-templated silver clusters. Silver cluster design and discovery will be carried out with novel machine learning algorithms that learn from experimental materials and inform design. The optimized NIR biolabels will be employed to study endocrine hormones central to metabolic and cardiovascular disease and will also be broadly applicable for biomedical research in other areas, such as tumor formation and metastasis. Undergraduate and graduate student researchers participating in this project will receive multidisciplinary training at the unique intersection of biophotonics, nanomaterials, and data science, and research opportunities for undergraduates will focus on California community college students and transfer students. 

In the second near-infrared window (NIR-II: 1,000-1,700 nm), biological tissues are transparent up to several centimeters depth, making this spectral window ideal for deep tissue imaging. However, most NIR-II fluorophores suffer from low fluorescence brightness, toxicity, or large physical size. This project investigates promising yet underexplored fluorescent DNA-templated silver clusters (Ag-DNAs) to develop small, stable, and modular NIR-II biolabels with broad applicability for deep tissue imaging. Ag-DNAs are composed of 10-30 silver atoms stabilized by short DNA oligonucleotides, with 500-1000 nm fluorescence colors selected by the DNA sequence. High throughput experimentation and custom multi-objective machine learning models will be developed to significantly extend the color palette of Ag-DNAs into the NIR-II and optimize Ag-DNAs as stable, biocompatible fluorophores. As a proof-of-principle, designed NIR-II-Ag-DNAs will be chemically attached to endocrine hormone proteins to track metabolic hormones in vivo. This project significantly advances the scientific framework for engineering metal clusters as novel fluorophores and, more broadly, for data-driven design of biopolymer-based biophotonic materials.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This collaborative project developed a new class of small, bright, biocompatible, and near-infrared (NIR) emitting fluorophores for deep tissue biological imaging in the tissue transparency window. At NIR wavelengths, biological tissues and fluids become far more transparent to light. However, there is a general lack of suitable contrast agents that would enable NIR fluorescence imaging deep into tissues and living organisms. This project was motivated by the technological need for new probes to enable light-based deep tissue imaging.

We exploited a promising yet underexplored nanophotonic material, the DNA-templated silver cluster (AgN-DNA), together with high-throughput experimental screening and custom machine learning and artificial intelligence models, to design new NIR emitting fluorophores. Using machine learning-guided experiments, we designed and experimentally synthesized over 200 novel AgN-DNAs with peak emission > 800 nm. Our discoveries include the first known AgN-DNAs with peak emission > 1,000 nm, in the second tissue transparency window. We also made the unexpected discovery that certain AgN-DNAs with enhanced chemical stabilities are stabilized by chloride ligands, which can significantly improve biocompatibility of these probes. Our investigation of a chloride-protected AgN-DNA with known crystal structure enabled the first electronic structure calculations for a realistic AgN-DNA system, enhancing fundamental knowledge of photophysical processes in these nanoclusters. We identified key chemical synthesis strategies to enhance yields of NIR emitting AgN-DNAs. Finally, we uncovered correlations between the composition and surface chemistry of AgN-DNAs and the fluorescence and chiroptical properties of these emitters.

This project led to discovery of numerous new NIR-emitting probes that may enable new biomedical imaging modalities for diverse applications, tissue types, and systems. Moreover, this research project contributed a general framework for developing, training and applying machine learning models to design sequence-encoded biomolecules with desired properties. This framework may help guide the development of emerging biomolecular materials beyond just AgN-DNAs.

This project enhanced the education and career development of K-12, college, and post-college trainees. Numerous participating graduate, undergraduate, and community college students and postdoctoral scholars received critical training and research opportunities at the intersection of biophotonics, AI, and nanochemistry. This unique multidisciplinary training will prepare these individuals to become future innovators who will drive the development of AI across multiple disciplines, with applications across natural sciences and engineering. Several excellent undergraduate and community college researchers coauthored publications that have resulted from this project. Moreover, we developed hands-on demonstrations that illustrate key scientific concepts from this project for K-12 students. These activities can be performed with simple household items and can be guided virtually, providing educators with an accessible tool to reach students from a wide range of backgrounds and in a wide range of settings. Demos were implemented through virtual and in-person events at local schools, museums, and summer programs.


Last Modified: 12/18/2024
Modified by: Petko Bogdanov
